questions.text: During muscle contraction, which best describes the role of the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) and the ryanodine receptor (RyR) in skeletal muscle?

choices.text: DHPR inhibits RyR to prevent calcium release.
DHPR activates RyR to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
RyR reuptakes calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
DHPR releases calcium directly into the muscle cytoplasm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DHPR activates RyR to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.


Explanation:
DHPR, located in the T-tubules, senses the action potential and undergoes a conformational change. This change directly activates RyR, the calcium release channel on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to the release of calcium ions into the cytoplasm, which is crucial for muscle contraction.

Sarcotubular System:

  • The Sarcotubular system is composed of the L tubule and T tubule .
  • The T-tubule contains a L-type voltage gated Calcium channel, known as the DHPR (dihydropyridine receptor channel).
  • The L-tubule contains a calcium channel known as RyR ryanodine receptor channel).

DHPR activates, not inhibits, RyR to facilitate calcium release during muscle contraction. (Option A)


The reuptake of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum is performed by the SERCA pump, not by RyR. (Option C)

DHPR does not release calcium directly; it activates RyR to release calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm. (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the changes in the sarcomere during muscle contraction with their corresponding descriptions:

1. A band

2. H band

3. I band

4. M line

Descriptions:

A. Decreases or disappears during contraction

B. Length remains the same during contraction

C. Becomes more prominent during contraction

D. Decreases in length during contraction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C


Explanation:

  • A-band: The length of the A-band remains the same during muscle contraction because it corresponds to the length of the myosin filaments, which do not change.
  • H-band: The H-band decreases or disappears as the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments during contraction, reducing the region where only myosin is present.
  • I-band: The length of the I-band decreases as the sarcomere shortens and the actin filaments overlap more with the myosin filaments.
  • M-line: The M-line becomes more prominent as it marks the central point of the sarcomere where the thick filaments are anchored.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the types of heat generated during muscle contraction and relaxation?

choices.text: Resting heat is produced during relaxation; activation heat during contraction.
Activation heat is produced during relaxation; shortening heat during rest.
Resting heat is produced at rest; activation, shortening, and relaxation heat during various phases of muscle activity.
Shortening heat is produced during rest; relaxation heat during contraction.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Resting heat is produced at rest; activation, shortening, and relaxation heat during various phases of muscle activity.

 

Explanation:

Types of heat generated during muscle contraction and relaxation:

  1. Resting Heat:
    • Resting heat refers to the heat produced by the muscle at rest.
    • It is generated by the basal metabolic processes that occur in the muscle even when it is not actively contracting.
  2. Activation Heat:
    • Activation heat is generated at the onset of muscle contraction.
    • This heat results from the initial metabolic processes that prepare the muscle fibers for contraction, including the breakdown of ATP and the activation of the contractile machinery.
  3. Shortening Heat:
    • Shortening heat is produced during the actual shortening of the muscle fibers.
    • This occurs as the muscle generates force and performs work, converting chemical energy into mechanical energy and heat.
  4. Relaxation Heat:
    • Relaxation heat is generated as the muscle returns to its resting state after contraction.
    • This phase involves processes such as the re-synthesis of ATP, the re-establishment of ion gradients, and the removal of metabolic byproducts.

 

Resting heat is not produced during relaxation. It is the heat generated by the muscle at rest, due to basal metabolic activities. Activation heat is correctly associated with the contraction phase. (Option A)

 

Activation heat is not produced during relaxation; it occurs at the onset of contraction. Shortening heat is not generated during rest; it is produced when muscle fibers actively shorten during contraction.(Option B)

 

Shortening heat is not produced during rest. Relaxation heat is not generated during contraction; it occurs during the relaxation phase as the muscle returns to its resting state. (Option D)

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of shortness of breath and fatigue during physical activity. Upon examination, the physician notes an elevated jugular venous pressure and an S3 heart sound. Echocardiography reveals dilated cardiac chambers with reduced ejection fraction. The physician explains that the heart is failing to pump efficiently, in part due to the length-tension relationship of the cardiac muscle.

Which of the following best explains the difference between the length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle relevant to this patient's condition?

choices.text: The operating point for both skeletal and cardiac muscles is at the same point on the tension curve
Skeletal muscle generates maximal tension at near resting length, while cardiac muscle generates maximal tension at slightly shorter lengths.
Skeletal muscle maintains tension over a wider range of sarcomere lengths than cardiac muscle.
Both muscles lose tension rapidly when the sarcomere length is significantly shortened or stretched beyond optimal length.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Skeletal muscle generates maximal tension at near resting length, while cardiac muscle generates maximal tension at slightly longer lengths.

Explanation:

Skeletal muscle generates maximal tension when sarcomere length is near resting length (about 2.0 to 2.2 micrometers), while cardiac muscle generates maximal tension at slightly longer lengths due to the rising part of the active tension curve, which allows for greater force production as the heart fills with more blood.

 

  • In skeletal muscle, the operating point is at the plateau of the active tension curve, where maximal tension is achieved at resting length. In cardiac muscle, the operating point is on the rising part of the active tension curve, allowing room for additional stretching and increased force production. (Option A)
  • Skeletal muscle tension decreases sharply if the sarcomere length deviates significantly from its optimal range. Cardiac muscle, due to its basket-weave fiber arrangement and early starting passive tension curve, is adapted to maintain near-maximal tension over a range of sarcomere lengths, crucial for its function in varying blood volumes. (Option C)
  • Both muscle types lose tension if sarcomere lengths are significantly altered from their optimal range. However, cardiac muscle’s passive tension curve starts earlier, and its fibers’ basket-weave pattern allows it to recoil with significant force, enabling it to maintain function over a broader range of lengths compared to skeletal muscle. (Option D)

questions.text: Which statement best describes the length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle?

choices.text: The maximum tension is generated when the sarcomere length is 1.6 μm.
The number of cross-bridges and the tension generated decrease when the sarcomere length exceeds 2.2 μm.
Passive tension contributes to muscle tension even when the sarcomere length is optimal.
The sarcomere ruptures when the length exceeds 2.2 μm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The number of cross-bridges and tension generated decrease when the sarcomere length exceeds 2.2 μm.

 

Explanation:

The length-tension relationship in skeletal muscle:

  • Optimal Length: The sarcomere length that produces maximum tension is between 2.0 and 2.2 μm. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cross-Bridge Formation: Tension is greatest at this optimal length because cross-bridge formation between actin and myosin filaments is maximized.
  • Short Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are shorter than optimal, excessive overlap of actin filaments limits cross-bridge formation, reducing tension.
  • Long Sarcomere Length: When sarcomeres are longer than optimal, cross-bridge formation decreases as actin and myosin filaments overlap less, leading to reduced tension.
  • Maximum Stretch: At lengths around 3.6 μm, the sarcomere can rupture due to excessive stretching. (Option D ruled out)

Passive Tension: Passive tension in muscle is the force generated by the stretching of the muscle's connective tissue structures. It arises due to the elasticity of the muscle's structural components, such as the titin protein, which resists excessive stretching.

  • Passive tension increases as the muscle is stretched beyond its optimal sarcomere length, contributing to the total tension experienced by the muscle.
  • While it is true that passive tension contributes to the total muscle tension at all lengths, option C is misleading because it implies that passive tension is a significant contributor even when the sarcomere length is optimal (2.0 to 2.2 μm).
  • The primary focus of the optimal length is on the maximal active tension generated by cross-bridge interactions, not the passive elastic properties of the muscle.

questions.text: Rigor mortis is a postmortem change resulting in the stiffening of muscles. Which of the following best explains the biochemical basis of rigor mortis in relation to the cross-bridge cycle in skeletal muscle?

choices.text: Increased calcium ion concentration in the sarcoplasm leads to continuous muscle contraction.
Depletion of ATP prevents the detachment of myosin heads from actin filaments.
Accumulation of lactic acid in muscles causes a permanent contraction.
Degradation of muscle proteins leads to muscle stiffness.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Depletion of ATP prevents the detachment of myosin heads from actin filaments.

 

Explanation:

  • In the cross-bridge cycle, ATP is essential for the detachment of myosin heads from actin filaments after a power stroke.
  • In the absence of ATP, myosin heads remain bound to actin, leading to a state of continuous contraction, which is observed as muscle stiffness in rigor mortis.
  • This process begins several hours after death and continues until muscle proteins begin to decompose.

Cross Bridge Formation:

  • Calcium ions play a crucial role in initiating muscle contraction by binding to troponin, which allows myosin to bind to actin. However, rigor mortis occurs due to the lack of ATP, which is necessary for the detachment of myosin from actin after contraction.(Option A)
  • Lactic acid accumulation in muscles is typically associated with anaerobic metabolism during vigorous exercise, leading to muscle fatigue and soreness. (Option C)
  • Degradation of muscle proteins leads to the eventual resolution of rigor mortis, not its onset. As the body decomposes, proteolytic enzymes break down muscle proteins, leading to the relaxation of the muscles and the end of rigor mortis. (Option D)

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence to describe the molecular mechanism of muscle contraction:


	Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin
	Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
	Binding of calcium ions to troponin C
	Detachment of the myosin head from actin
	Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head
	Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2, 3, 1, 6, 4, 5


Explanation:

Sequential events during muscle contraction

Release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

An action potential triggers the release of calcium ions (Ca²⁺) from the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm of the muscle cell.

Binding of calcium ions to troponin C

Calcium ions bind to troponin C on the thin filaments, causing a conformational change in the troponin complex.

Cross-bridge formation between myosin and actin

The conformational change in the troponin complex moves tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing the myosin heads (with ADP and Pi bound) to attach to the exposed binding sites on actin.

Power stroke, moving the myosin head from 90 degrees to 45 degrees

The myosin head pivots from a 90-degree angle to a 45-degree angle, pulling the actin filament toward the center of the sarcomere. ADP and Pi are released during this movement.

Detachment of the myosin head from actin

A new ATP molecule binds to the myosin head, causing it to detach from the actin filament.

Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi, re-cocking the myosin head

The ATP is hydrolyzed to ADP and Pi, providing energy to re-cock the myosin head back to the 90-degree position, ready for another cycle of contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the regulatory proteins of skeletal muscle is incorrect?

choices.text: Tropomyosin prevents actin-myosin attachment in a resting muscle.
Tropomyosin is a filamentous protein, while troponin is a spherical protein consisting of 3 subunits.
Troponin C can bind with up to 4 calcium ions at a time, which initiates a conformational change in the troponin complex.
Troponin I attaches to tropomyosin, anchoring the troponin complex to the actin filament.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Troponin I attaches to tropomyosin, anchoring the troponin complex to the actin filament.

Explanation:
Regulatory proteins play crucial roles in the contraction of skeletal muscles by controlling the interaction between actin and myosin filaments. Regulatory proteins are of 2 main types:

  • Tropomyosin
  • Troponin Complex ( Troponin C, Troponin T & Troponin I)

Regulatory Protein

Function

Tropomyosin
  • Spiral-shaped filamentous protein wrapped around actin filaments. (Option B ruled out)
  • Blocks myosin-binding sites on actin in a resting muscle, preventing muscle contraction. (Option A ruled out)
  • Known as the gatekeeper molecule of muscle contraction.

Troponin T
  • Attached to tropomyosin.
  • Anchors the troponin complex to the actin filament.

Troponin I
  • Acts as the inhibitory subunit of troponin.
  • Helps position tropomyosin over myosin-binding sites on actin, preventing actin-myosin interaction in a resting muscle.

Troponin C
  • Binds with calcium ions, up to 4 ions at a time (Option C)
  • The binding of calcium ions causes a conformational change in the troponin complex, moving tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin, allowing muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the sliding filament mechanism of muscle contraction?

choices.text: The sarcomere shortens as actin filaments slide over myosin filaments.
Contraction is triggered by action potential causing the release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
The I-band & H-zone shortens and can disappear during full contraction.
Calcium ions bind to tropomyosin, allowing myosin to attach to actin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Calcium ions bind to tropomyosin, allowing myosin to attach to actin.

Explanation:
The sliding filament theory describes the process by which muscles contract to produce force. It involves the following key steps:

  1. Initiation: An action potential travels down a motor neuron to the neuromuscular junction, causing the release of acetylcholine.
  2. Calcium Release: Acetylcholine triggers an action potential in the muscle, leading to the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. (Option B ruled out)
  3. Binding of Calcium to Troponin C: Calcium ions bind to troponin C, a regulatory protein. This binding causes a conformational change in the troponin-tropomyosin complex.
  4. Exposure of Myosin-Binding Sites: The conformational change moves tropomyosin away from the myosin-binding sites on actin filaments, allowing myosin heads to bind to actin.
  5. Cross-Bridge Formation: Myosin heads, energized by the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and inorganic phosphate, attach to the exposed binding sites on actin, forming cross-bridges.
  6. Power Stroke: The myosin heads pivot, pulling the actin filaments toward the center of the sarcomere, shortening the sarcomere. (Option A ruled out)
  7. Detachment and Reattachment: ATP binds to myosin heads, causing them to detach from actin. The ATP is then hydrolyzed, re-energizing the myosin heads for another cycle.

 

I-band shortens during contraction as the actin filaments slide over the myosin filaments. H-zone is the region within the A-band where there is only myosin and no overlapping actin. Both disappear during full contraction. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
Match the labeled parts of the sarcomere (A, B, C, D, E) with their correct names.

1. Z-line
2. I-band
3. M-line
4. A-band
5. H-zone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A-3, B-1, C-5, D-4, E-2

Explanation:

  • A (M-line): The M-line is the center of the sarcomere and the H-zone, where the thick filaments are anchored.
  • B (Z-line): The Z-line marks the boundary between adjacent sarcomeres and anchors the thin filaments.
  • C (H-zone): The H-zone is the central region of the A-band where there are only thick filaments, with no thin filament overlap.
  • D (A-band): The A-band is the length of the thick filaments, which remains constant during contraction.
  • E (I-band): The I-band is the region of the sarcomere that contains only thin filaments.

questions.text: A 25-year-old athlete presents with muscle pain following intense exercise. A muscle biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination reveals the structural organization of muscle tissue. Which of the following correctly matches the muscle components with their descriptions?

choices.text: Fascicle - individual muscle cell; Fibre - bundle of myofibrils; Myofibril - contains contractile proteins; Contractile protein - forms entire muscle.
Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibres; Fibre - single muscle cell; Myofibril - contains sarcomeres; Contractile protein - actin and myosin.
Fascicle - single muscle cell; Fibre - contains sarcomeres; Myofibril - bundle of fascicles; Contractile protein - forms myofibrils
Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibres; Fibre - contains sarcomeres; Myofibril - individual muscle cell; Contractile protein - actin and myosin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fascicle - bundle of muscle fibers; Fibre - single muscle cell; Myofibril - contains sarcomeres; Contractile protein - actin and myosin

Explanation:
Skeletal muscles are composed of multiple bundles called fascicles- which are made of individual muscle fibers (muscle cells)- muscle cells are made of multiple myofibrils- which are made up of contractile protein molecules- Actin and Myosin.

questions.text: Examine the image of a sarcomere below. Which band is indicated by the X ?

choices.text: A band
I band
Z disc
H zone

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A band

Explanation:

  • A band: The dark band, anisotropic to polarized light. It contains the entire length of the myosin filaments. The ends of the actin filaments also overlap with the myosin filaments in this band.
  • I band: The light band, isotropic to polarized light. It contains only actin filaments.(Option B ruled out)
  • Z disk: A structure composed of filamentous proteins (alpha-actinin) that bisects the I band. Actin filaments attach to the Z disk and extend from it in both directions to interdigitate with myosin filaments. Z disks also pass from myofibril to myofibril, attaching them together across the muscle fiber.(Option C ruled out)
  • H zone: Located at the center of the A band, this zone contains only myosin filaments and appears lighter than the rest of the A band.(Option D ruled out)
  • M line: A structure that runs down the center of the H zone, providing structural support for the myosin filaments.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding nerve-muscle physiology?

choices.text: SERCA is a protein of skeletal muscle encoded by gene ATP2A1
Secondary active transport mechanism involving the NCX protein seen in skeletal muscle.
Calsequestrin protein is present only in smooth muscle
Calreticulin protein is present in cardiac muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) SERCA is a protein molecule encoded by the gene ATP2A1

 

Explanation:

Sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca+ ATPase (SERCA) pump is a protein molecule encoded by gene ATP2A1.

  • SERCA is a calcium–adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) pump that helps transport calcium ions back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum from the muscle fiber, which leads to muscle relaxation.
  • It is present in both skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle.

Sodium-Calcium Exchanger: Cardiac muscle also utilizes a sodium-calcium exchanger to remove calcium ions from the cell.

  • This exchanger allows sodium to enter the cell while simultaneously transporting calcium out.
  • The sodium that enters the cell during this process is then removed by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump
  • Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX) is primarily involved in calcium handling in cardiac muscle, not skeletal muscle (Option B ruled out)

Two proteins found within the sarcoplasmic reticulum include:

  • Calsequestrin protein: Found in skeletal muscle, myocardium, and smooth muscle. (Option C ruled out)
  • Calreticulin protein: Located specifically in smooth muscle tissue.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old man undergoing surgery for a fractured tibia experiences a sudden onset of muscle rigidity, a rapid heart rate, and a high fever shortly after receiving general anesthesia. Mutation in which of the following channels is involved in this condition?

choices.text: RyR1
RyR2
CaV
NaV

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) RyR1

Explanation:
The symptoms of muscle rigidity, high fever, and rapid heart rate clinically represent Malignant Hyperthermia. A gain of mutation of the RyR1 channel causes excessive calcium release and causes muscle rigidity.

RyR2 (Option B) – Mutations cause catecholaminergic polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (CPVT), leading to life-threatening arrhythmias during stress or exercise.

CaV (Option C) – Mutations in calcium voltage-gated channels cause hypokalemic periodic paralysis and certain forms of congenital myopathy.

NaV (Option D) – Mutations in sodium voltage-gated channels cause paramyotonia congenita, hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, and some forms of epilepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes a unique characteristic of excitation-contraction coupling in cardiac muscle compared to skeletal muscle?

choices.text: T-tubules are absent, and calcium influx solely relies on diffusion through the sarcolemma.
Calcium-induced calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is mediated by ryanodine receptors alone.
Extracellular calcium entry into T-tubules contributes significantly to calcium influx during the plateau phase of the action potential.
Relaxation of cardiac muscle is primarily initiated by potassium binding to troponin.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Extracellular calcium entry through T-tubule membrane contributes significantly to calcium influx during the plateau phase of the action potential.
 

Explanation:
Unlike skeletal muscle, cardiac T-tubules are open to the extracellular space, allowing extracellular calcium influx during the plateau phase of the action potential. This influx is critical for sustaining calcium levels necessary for prolonged contraction in cardiac muscle. This phenomenon is stated as Calcium-induced calcium release.

CONTRACTION IN CARDIAC MUSCLE

 

 

T-tubules are present in both cardiac and skeletal muscle, and they are essential for transmitting the action potential into the interior of the muscle fiber(Option C)


Calcium-induced calcium release in cardiac muscle involves both voltage-gated calcium channels in the T-tubules and ryanodine receptors on the SR membrane (Option C)


Relaxation of cardiac muscle is primarily initiated by the removal of calcium ions from the cytoplasm, facilitated by the sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA), and not by potassium binding to troponin (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following events directly results in the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin filaments during skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: ATP binding to myosin heads
Depolarization of T-tubules
Binding of acetylcholine (ACh) to muscle fiber receptors
Conformational change in troponin complex

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Conformational change in troponin complex

 

Explanation:

The conformational change in the troponin complex occurs in response to elevated cytoplasmic calcium ions (Ca²⁺), which bind to troponin. This causes tropomyosin to move away from the myosin-binding sites on actin filaments, allowing myosin heads to bind with Myosin binding sites of actin and initiate muscle contraction.

 

CONTRACTION OF SKELETAL MUSCLE:

 

ATP binding allows myosin heads to detach from actin filaments during muscle relaxation, not contraction. (Option A)

Depolarization of T-tubules allows for the propagation of the action potential into the muscle fiber but does not directly expose myosin-binding sites on actin filaments. (Option B)

Binding of acetylcholine (ACh) to muscle fiber receptors initiates muscle fiber depolarization but does not directly expose myosin-binding sites on actin filaments. (Option C)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and frequent falls. His symptoms started around the age of 5 and have gradually worsened. Physical examination reveals calf hypertrophy and a positive Gower's sign. Laboratory tests show elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Genetic testing identifies a mutation in the dystrophin gene leading to the complete absence of dystrophin protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
Becker Muscular Dystrophy
Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy
Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

Explanation:
The progressive muscle weakness, difficulty walking, and frequent falls starting at age 5, along with calf hypertrophy, a positive Gower’s sign, and elevated creatine kinase, are classic findings of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Genetic testing confirms a dystrophin gene mutation leading to complete absence of dystrophin, which is a characteristic finding

Becker Muscular Dystrophy (BMD) (Option B) also involves mutations in the dystrophin gene but usually presents later (adolescence or adulthood) with a slower progression and milder symptoms. Calf hypertrophy can be seen in both BMD and DMD, but the overall course and severity of BMD are milder.

Emery-Dreifuss Muscular Dystrophy (EDMD) (Option C) often presents with early contractures, cardiac involvement (conduction defects, arrhythmias), and humeroperoneal muscle weakness. It does not typically involve calf hypertrophy and has a different pattern of muscle weakness compared to DMD.

Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD) (Option D) primarily affects the muscles of the face, shoulders, and upper arms. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with a distinct pattern of muscle weakness that spares the lower limbs until later stages.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty climbing stairs, running, and lifting objects, and have noticed that his muscle weakness has gradually worsened. A muscle biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemical staining shows an absence of a key protein at the sarcolemma. Which of the following proteins is most likely absent, leading to this clinical presentation?

choices.text: Dystrophin
Myosin
Actin
Troponin

questions.solution:
Explanation:
Dystrophin is a key protein associated with the sarcolemma, the membrane surrounding muscle fibers. It plays a critical role in maintaining the structural integrity of muscle cells by linking the internal cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix.The progressive muscle weakness, difficulty with climbing stairs and lifting objects, and absence of a key sarcolemmal protein on biopsy suggest Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD), which is caused by the absence of dystrophin.

 

  • Myosin (Option B) and Actin (Option C) are essential contractile proteins within the muscle fibers themselves, not specifically associated with the sarcolemma.
  • Troponin (Option D) is a regulatory protein complex involved in muscle contraction but is located within the muscle fiber, not at the sarcolemma.
